commit_message:
Add asterisk to conditionally required fields

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/552247/ introduced a way to
add asterisk mark to conditionally required fields.

This commit covers several known forms:
- Create Network / Create Subnet
- Create Port
- Attach Interface to Instance
- Add Security Group Rule

Change-Id: I809c23fd64dc2f379c3fdb585741c6b266ec5b1b
Closes-Bug: #1420370
Closes-Bug: #1292165
Closes-Bug: #1755131

commit_message:
Use the new dnsmasq PXE filter in ironic-inspector

With the introduction of rotued networks there can be
a situation where baremetal nodes on remote segments
are unintentionally introspected. Using the dnsmasq
based PXE filtering driver in ironic inspector fixes
the issue.

Co-Authored-By: Harald Jensås <hjensas@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1756075
Change-Id: I53d6c5718c7f9112d578ec6f73830830d2c71737
Depends-On: I056cdadc025f35d8b6fd22f510a7c0a8e259a1f0
(cherry picked from commit 5e1a4d9f0bbc2afa98727cf192fc174194abc8e8)

commit_message:
avoid verbose tracebacks on known errors

- log that no pollsters loaded rather than throwing error
- ipmi are expected to be missing as note says, just debug logs
with details rather than massive traceback.

Closes-Bug: #1747536
Change-Id: Ib592c84dca017e94c66aad0170f0317e514fd747
(cherry picked from commit 35f65339992c320b8aab89dab2517281d225d01b)

subject: Amend the member_of spec for multiple query sets
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 1063, 'name': 'Ed Leafe', 'email': 'ed@leafe.com', 'username': 'ed-leafe'}, {'_account_id': 4393, 'name': 'Dan Smith', 'email': 'dms@danplanet.com', 'username': 'danms'}, {'_account_id': 5754, 'name': 'Alex Xu', 'email': 'hejie.xu@intel.com', 'username': 'xuhj'}, {'_account_id': 6873, 'name': 'Matt Riedemann', 'email': 'mriedem.os@gmail.com', 'username': 'mriedem'}, {'_account_id': 11564, 'name': 'Chris Dent', 'email': 'cdent@anticdent.org', 'username': 'chdent'}, {'_account_id': 14070, 'name': 'Eric Fried', 'email': 'openstack@fried.cc', 'username': 'efried'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-03-22 18:32:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-03-22 18:48:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

Yup.

-1 to ack that we need to pick our poison before this flies.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-03-22 18:56:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-03-22 18:56:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

-2 to make sure nobody merges this before we have the decision point :)'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2018-03-22 19:15:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I would really like to avoid new punctuation with semantic meaning in our URLs. Let's stick to standard HTTP and use multiple member_of entries separated by '&'."}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2018-03-23 02:10:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Only 'member_of' in 'GET /resource_providers' uses 'in:' or OR logic. We use 'required' with comma without any operator as AND logic.

If using multiple `member_of` entries separated by '&', a little confuse what is mean for "member_of=in:agg_1,agg2&member_of=in:agg3,agg4''}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-03-23 22:24:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Only 'member_of' in 'GET /resource_providers' uses 'in:' or OR logic. We use 'required' with comma without any operator as AND logic.

I agree this seems contradictory at first, but the comma is saying the same thing in both cases.

- resources=a,b,c => "I want resources a AND b AND c"
- member_of=in:a,b,c => "must be a member of *any* aggregate IN (a AND b AND c)"

> If using multiple `member_of` entries separated by '&', a little confuse what is mean for "member_of=in:agg_1,agg2&member_of=in:agg3,agg4'

Likewise (again agreeing it's confusing without really laying it out) I think this is nice and explicit:

- member_of=in:agg1,agg2&member_of=in:agg3,agg4 => "[must be a member of any aggregate in (agg1, agg2)] AND [must be a member of any aggregate in (agg3, agg4)]"

I'm starting to prefer this over the punctuation option; I'll add my vote to Ed's.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2018-03-24 00:17:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Actually doesn't want to over the punctuation also. Just want to use the operator before the value list. We can use "member_of=and:a,b,c". The "member_of=a,b,c" is default to and operator. That is more consistent current design I think.

For the [a or b] and [c or d], i'm not sure the real use-case, But I can see a difference. For each complex logic, even with operator based, single parameter can't express that. It still needs multiple parameters. If [a or b] and [c or d] is a possible use-case, yea I +1 for Ed.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-03-26 12:24:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

I'm fine with member_of=in:foo,bar&member_of=in:snap,cap

As long as it is documented I don't think it is a severe consistency problem; the way we've written things you have to be rather aware of how things work in order to construct any queries of consequence (rather than just throwing things at the server).

We should probably (although we shouldn't delay this to do it) make sure that our schema handling expresses when multi is okay and when it is not."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-03-26 14:27:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> For the [a or b] and [c or d], i'm not sure the real use-case

I put the real use-case in the spec addition here. I need to be able to say "one of the tenant-allowed aggregates AND the az aggregate they asked for". The reason for making this change is specifically so I can go implement that thing :)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-03-26 14:31:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I agree this seems contradictory at first, but the comma is saying
 > the same thing in both cases.

The thing that makes it different for me is the "in:" prefix. If you use a command in an "in:" statement, then it means "in one of these", also written as "an OR".

 > I'm starting to prefer this over the punctuation option; I'll add
 > my vote to Ed's.

Okay, so sounds like you, me, ed, and cdent are all +1 on the non-punctuation approach, right? I'm not sure I grok'd Alex's latest comment, as "member_of=and:a,b" doesn't help the use-case being proposed at the moment.

Eric, if you ack the above, I'll spin this to be more declarative of the non-punctuation approach and remove my -2 so we can actually vote.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-03-26 14:51:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I prefer:

 member_of=in:AGG_TENANT_X,AGG_TENANT_Y&member_of=in:AGG_AZ_1,AGG_AZ_2

as well.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-03-26 23:57:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Eric, if you ack the above

My name is Eric, and I ack the above.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-03-27 14:49:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-03-27 14:53:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

pep8 and...'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-03-27 14:55:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-03-27 14:55:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-03-27 14:58:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

Good stuff.'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2018-03-27 15:03:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

This approach to ANDing is much cleaner.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2018-03-27 15:06:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

I'm cool with that."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-03-27 15:07:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

yup, good enough, ship it, make it so, onward'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-03-27 15:31:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

Yeah, I likee.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-28 15:35:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-03-28 15:37:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-28 15:38:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: -Code-Review

I didn't see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/555413/3/specs/rocky/approved/alloc-candidates-member-of.rst@172 indicating this would in fact be a new microversion, not just changing 1.21."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-28 15:38:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-28 15:39:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only zvm: recheck in the comment. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-15578 : SUCCESS in 1h 29m 28s'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-03-28 10:52:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

- nova-dsvm-full-tempest http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/557187/1/ : SUCCESS in 2h 20m 10s'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-03-28 12:31:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Oh, this is worse than a spelling mistake.  We clearly need a test that exercises this code path.  Would you please add one?'}, {'account_id': 26250, 'date': '2018-03-28 12:38:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Oh, this is worse than a spelling mistake.  We clearly need a test
 > that exercises this code path.  Would you please add one?

Sorry, I don't know how, as this seems to happen only if two things run in parallel and something deletes an object right after the other got its list of objects. How would you test this reliably?"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-03-28 12:44:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Heh, whoops, clearly the guarded condition doesn't happen that often...

I agree that creating a test is a pain. We probably just need to up our review game (which is a well-known thing already)."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-03-28 13:03:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Sorry guys, I didn't realize we didn't have a framework in place already that would make it trivial to write such a test.

Thank you for the fix, Johannes!"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-03-28 13:06:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

Fast-approving this. Had a brief conversation on IRC about whether adding a unit test for this was worth it. We concluded it was not, since a) we don't have unit tests for the placement HTTP handlers (and would not ask you to create one from scratch) and b) adding a Gabbi functional test that exercised this code path would be non-trivial due to the need to have multiple executor threads and rely on a certain timing to happen.

So, I'm just merging this. :)

-jay"}]

commit_message:
XenAPI: Add guide document for XenServer

Now we can support OpenStack services deployment on XenServer by
using Kolla. This commit is to amend the document.

Change-Id: I08613c1b77b22cf7d2e695f569497727d3a4c101
blueprint: xenserver-support

(4 comments)

Some issues with the management of 'in:', potentially a missing file, and a response to Jay within.

Also is "any" the meaning we want in this context? It maps to what is done on /resource_providers but is it the semantic we want for allocation candidates? I'm not entirely sure.

The leading use case is "limit the results to a particular single host aggregate". Do we next want "one of these host aggregates" or "all of these host aggregates".

Or, bless us, do we want to be able to express both?'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2018-03-13 12:29:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Add 'member_of' param to GET /allocation_candidates

The call to GET /allocation_candidates now accepts a 'member_of'
parameter, representing one or more aggregate UUIDs. If this parameter
is supplied, the allocation_candidates returned will be limited to those
with resource_providers that belong to at least one of the supplied
aggregates.

Blueprint: alloc-candidates-member-of

Change-Id: I5857e927a830914c96e040936804e322baccc24c

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-27 12:28:44.000000000', 'message': 'Replace assert to raise AssertionError and eliminate possible insecure
usage of temp file/directory.

This patch is a fix for the issue B101 assert_used found by bandit
scanner.
As assert functionality could be turned off by the -O option for python
interpreter, assert statements were replaced to raise AssertionError.
This patch is a fix for the issue B108: hardcoded_tmp_directory
found by bandit scanner.

The main reasoning for that are rest code after assert could be not
ready for values that assert filters and the need for safely creating
a temporary file or directory.

commit_message:
Replace assert to raise AssertionError

This patch is a fix for the issue B101 assert_used found by bandit
scanner.
As assert functionality could be turned off by the -O option for python
interpreter, assert statements were replaced to raise AssertionError.

The main reasoning for that is rest code after assert could be not
ready for values that assert filters.

Related-Bug: #1759250
Change-Id: I05fa067bf2b7fd865672f8e8e094aeb2950fe220

commit_message:
Fix missing permissions on Swift rebalance playbook

The playbook is executed as user heat-admin on the nodes, and some tasks
need to read and/or write to directories that are owned by the
containers (ie with a numeric id on the host itself).

Closes-Bug: 1759311
Change-Id: Ia766bc44a647fec15ff662f1ef9ffb67860b155b

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-28 09:18:06.000000000', 'message': "Update puppet-nova before running nova-manage

oslo_db_api.wrap_db_retry interface was changed, so retry_on_request was
removed without any backward compatibility.
Ic98f8cfeb6f78a7e066613787e7cbcea02fcec5c fixed that for nova. However, during
undercloud upgrade oslo packages were upgraded as it's required for undercloud
without taking into account that they might break interface for other packages.

This patch adds step for updating puppet-nova package before running
/usr/bin/nova-manage db online_data_migrations

Change-Id: I10d49e20c45ec9f25ca90d976309acdc78f7dd19
"}]
commit_message:
Update puppet-nova before running nova-manage

oslo_db_api.wrap_db_retry interface was changed, so retry_on_request was
removed without any backward compatibility.
Ic98f8cfeb6f78a7e066613787e7cbcea02fcec5c fixed that for nova. However, during
undercloud upgrade oslo packages were upgraded as it's required for undercloud
without taking into account that they might break interface for other packages.

This patch adds step for updating puppet-nova package before running
/usr/bin/nova-manage db online_data_migrations

Change-Id: I10d49e20c45ec9f25ca90d976309acdc78f7dd19

commit_message:
use plugin common utils from neutron-lib

The public APIs that are part of neutron.plugins.common.utils were
rehomed into neutron-lib with Iabb155b5d2d0ec6104ebee5dd42cf292bdf3ec61
and will removed in neutron with commit
I1d63cbea463e92e1d2e053f8e1a564ed52cb84f8

This patch consumes the common plugin utils from neutron-lib

NOTE: We will have to rehome create_port and consume it before we can
land the neutron patch.

Change-Id: I17c8f368c1305fe47d93b9dc4be2fe87d2f10b33

Change-Id: I29d230c16bee3e2d7e434f98c05af4a6a53ff10a
'}, {'created': '2018-03-28 13:31:18.000000000', 'message': "Ensure build/install works in serial/parallel execution

When executing the role in parallel, there is a race condition
due to all targets trying to build simultaneously and then all
trying to copy their packages back to the same folder on the
deployment host.

In this patch we implement the use of a dynamic group based on
the venv_reuse_download_subfolder which, by default, combines
the architecture and distribution data. When then use this
group to ensure that only the first of each group does the build
and the others consume the first host's package.

To validate whether builds happen properly, whether in serial
or parallel, and to also implement a way to implement tests for
future validations, we implement a test system using multiple
containers while allowing localhost to be the deployment host
only.

Change-Id: I29d230c16bee3e2d7e434f98c05af4a6a53ff10a
"}, {'created': '2018-03-28 13:38:08.000000000', 'message': "Ensure build/install works in serial/parallel execution

When executing the role in parallel, there is a race condition
due to all targets trying to build simultaneously and then all
trying to copy their packages back to the same folder on the
deployment host.

In this patch we implement the use of a dynamic group based on
the venv_reuse_download_subfolder which, by default, combines
the architecture and distribution data. When then use this
group to ensure that only the first of each group does the build
and the others consume the first host's package.

The conditional in tasks/python_venv_install.yml checking
whether the src venv is present was unnecessary given the same
conditional is present in tasks/main.yml. It interferes with
the new parallel execution capability, so it's been removed.

To validate whether builds happen properly, whether in serial
or parallel, and to also implement a way to implement tests for
future validations, we implement a test system using multiple
containers while allowing localhost to be the deployment host
only.

Change-Id: I29d230c16bee3e2d7e434f98c05af4a6a53ff10a
"}, {'created': '2018-03-28 13:43:06.000000000', 'message': "Ensure build/install works in serial/parallel execution

commit_message:
Ensure build/install works in serial/parallel execution

When executing the role in parallel, there is a race condition
due to all targets trying to build simultaneously and then all
trying to copy their packages back to the same folder on the
deployment host.

In this patch we implement the use of a dynamic group based on
the venv_reuse_download_subfolder which, by default, combines
the architecture and distribution data. We then use this group
to ensure that only the first of each group does the build and
the others consume the first host's package.

The conditional in tasks/python_venv_install.yml checking
whether the src venv is present was unnecessary given the same
conditional is present in tasks/main.yml. It interferes with
the new parallel execution capability, so it's been removed.

To validate whether builds happen properly, whether in serial
or parallel, and to also implement a way to implement tests for
future validations, we implement a test system using multiple
containers while allowing localhost to be the deployment host
only.

Change-Id: I29d230c16bee3e2d7e434f98c05af4a6a53ff10a

commit_message:
Make some tweaks to swift logging

This made some minor changes to the container management for logging,
mostly using copy_object to rotate logs, instead of get/put, and using
the idempotency of put_container for container creation.

Change-Id: I852184fcbdf9fb7e811e7ae203733e5e17f2c086

commit_message:
Remove limestone specific labels from nl02.o.o

We are ready to bring limestone backonline, remove our dedicate
testing labels and prepare to use default labels.

Change-Id: I9e2bdc05016f2bdb8638db7269c5af2ddc5fe12b
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Ensure to install latest neutron from master

neutron-vpnaas-dsvm-functional-sswan job requires neutron master branch
but after neutron was added to g-r neutron queens is installed.
Ideally this can be handled by tox-siblings with zuulv3 native job,
but it requires several efforts. This commit tries a work-around
just to pass the current broken func test.

Change-Id: I91fa5222031ad129f7fdfba5bf1bcb09c6d196ac

commit_message:
Remove usage of kwarg retry_on_request in API

As Retry on request is always enabled in class wrap_db_retry, so in the
new release, kwarg retry_on_request is deprecated for removal in oslo.db.

Change-Id: Ic98f8cfeb6f78a7e066613787e7cbcea02fcec5c
Closes-Bug: #1715270

commit_message:
bifrost-create-vm-nodes: Install virtualbmc to virtualenv if enabled

The various bifrost pip requirements can be installed in a virtual
environment except for virtualbmc which is always installed on the
real filesystem. As such, lets put this package in the virtual
environment as well if we are using one.

Change-Id: I74ca87cfb64df2deedf66ecf654a8a124d02e40c

in those tests.

for more details.

Change-Id: Ie26e8ffc7dc7620e7ea1b4e8004cff1f849f0b68
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: Ie26e8ffc7dc7620e7ea1b4e8004cff1f849f0b68
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

-1 is for the misc typos and such that other people have identified."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2017-10-03 16:20:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> @Stephen, to be clear, I'm not tracking this blueprint at all for
 > Queens. And while you're willing to work on making these changes, I
 > don't think we have people on the core team willing to spend time
 > reviewing changes to something that is pretty internal, just for
 > admin usage, and not a high enough priority to detract review
 > attention from other things we need to work on.

Yup, I realize this is purely tech debt, just like removing deprecated features, adding support for new external service API versions, etc. I would like to resolve it at some point and can keep bugging people to get it in. In any case though, I don't think we need a spec and that's the main thing."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-01-26 10:02:35.000000000', 'content': 'Restored'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-01-26 10:03:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-01-26 10:03:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-02-01 11:18:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-27 18:31:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

To be clear, I don't think we should spend time on this."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-03-28 13:53:18.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

I still don't get the disdain the old guard in nova have for tech debt stuff. Who knows though, maybe I'll be as jaded a few years down the line."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-28 14:14:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

> I still don't get the disdain the old guard in nova have for tech debt stuff. Who knows though, maybe I'll be as jaded a few years down the line.

It's not about enjoying tech debt, it's about picking and choosing the best tech debt things to spend our time, and I don't personally consider this a valuable use of our time when it comes to tech debt. For example, we could be working on fixing the age-old shared storage resource tracking issue, or removing nova-network from the tree."}]

commit_message:
Update overcloud-prep-containers script name.

After merging [0], the name set to the script
used to prepare containers before the upgrade
step hast changed. This patch sets the right
name in the featureset, so O->P job doesn't
fail.

[0] - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/540473/

Depends-On: I033ec0d0dd4fbf26b7231ca48d73f28c12e78b0f
Change-Id: I8cc94500c317c49cb68567f79f65f0e12fcd75ea
Closes-Bug: #1759060

commit_message:
Guide to ppa:juju/stable instead of devel

Previously ppa:juju/devel was required when Juju 2.x was not officially
released. Now stable releases of Juju 2.x are mature enough to be relied
on as a base of charm development.

Change-Id: I8067b232599716c2dc978f2cf5823dbb207e3617

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-28 09:43:38.000000000', 'message': 'Misc updates for ceph-volume support

Change-Id: I1675b67d364ae6042129a8a717d4bdffff5bde92
'}, {'created': '2018-03-28 10:11:05.000000000', 'message': 'Misc updates for ceph-volume support

Change-Id: I1675b67d364ae6042129a8a717d4bdffff5bde92
'}, {'created': '2018-03-28 10:24:59.000000000', 'message': "Misc updates for ceph-volume support

Add support for use of the new 'ceph-volume' method for
OSD block device management for Ceph >= 12.2.4 (where the
ceph-volume tool is consistently supported in Ubuntu).

This change requires that block devices be prepared in advance
of calls to ceph-volume (which does not partitioning or setup
of {PV,VG,LV}s).

Block devices are prepare with a single partition of type GPT;
The primary data device for an OSD is prepared with a single
VG and a single LV for bluestore, or two LV's for filestore.

Filestore:

  block /dev/sdb
    pv /dev/sdb1
        vg /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>/osd-data-<OSD-UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>/osd-journal-<OSD-UUID>

Bluestore:

  block /dev/sdb
    pv /dev/sdb1
        vg /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>/osd-block-<OSD-UUID>

If separate Filestore Journal or Bluestore DB and WAL devices
have been configured, appropriate {PV,VG,LV} configuration is
created on the configured block devices.

Filestore with Journal device:

  block /dev/sdb
    pv /dev/sdb1
        vg /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>/osd-data-<OSD-UUID>
  block /dev/sdc
    pv /dev/sdc1
        vg /dev/ceph-journal-<UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-journal-<UUID>/osd-journal-<OSD-UUID>

Bluestore with DB and WAL devices:

  block /dev/sdb
    pv /dev/sdb1
        vg /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>/osd-block-<OSD-UUID>
  block /dev/sdc
    pv /dev/sdc1
        vg /dev/ceph-db-<UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-db-<UUID>/osd-db-<OSD-UUID>
  block /dev/sdd
    pv /dev/sdd1
        vg /dev/ceph-wal-<UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-wal-<UUID>/osd-wal-<OSD-UUID>

ceph-volume makes extensive use of LVM tags to encode required
Ceph information directly into the LVM volume metadata - this
can be view using 'ceph-volume lvm list'.

ceph-volume managed devices are prepared and activated using the
'create' subcommand which differs somewhat from ceph-disk, where
OSD's are activated using udev triggers.

This review also switches to using the charmhelpers zap_disk
function to clean disks prior to use by ceph; this resolves an
outstanding issue with use of Ceph lockbox encryption with
ceph-disk. ceph-volume continues to support the encrypt config
option, applying LUKS based dm-crypt encryption to the LV's
supporting an OSD, with keys stored directly in the MON cluster.

Change-Id: I1675b67d364ae6042129a8a717d4bdffff5bde92
"}, {'created': '2018-03-28 13:24:41.000000000', 'message': "Misc updates for ceph-volume support

Add support for use of the new 'ceph-volume' method for
OSD block device management for Ceph >= 12.2.4 (where the
ceph-volume tool is consistently supported in Ubuntu).

This change requires that block devices be prepared in advance
of calls to ceph-volume (which does not partitioning or setup
of {PV,VG,LV}s).

Block devices are prepare with a single partition of type GPT;
The primary data device for an OSD is prepared with a single
VG and a single LV for bluestore, or two LV's for filestore.

Filestore:

  block /dev/sdb
    pv /dev/sdb1
        vg /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>/osd-data-<OSD-UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>/osd-journal-<OSD-UUID>

Bluestore:

  block /dev/sdb
    pv /dev/sdb1
        vg /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>/osd-block-<OSD-UUID>

If separate Filestore Journal or Bluestore DB and WAL devices
have been configured, appropriate {PV,VG,LV} configuration is
created on the configured block devices.

Filestore with Journal device:

  block /dev/sdb
    pv /dev/sdb1
        vg /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>/osd-data-<OSD-UUID>
  block /dev/sdc
    pv /dev/sdc1
        vg /dev/ceph-journal-<UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-journal-<UUID>/osd-journal-<OSD-UUID>

Bluestore with DB and WAL devices:

  block /dev/sdb
    pv /dev/sdb1
        vg /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>/osd-block-<OSD-UUID>
  block /dev/sdc
    pv /dev/sdc1
        vg /dev/ceph-db-<UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-db-<UUID>/osd-db-<OSD-UUID>
  block /dev/sdd
    pv /dev/sdd1
        vg /dev/ceph-wal-<UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-wal-<UUID>/osd-wal-<OSD-UUID>

ceph-volume makes extensive use of LVM tags to encode required
Ceph information directly into the LVM volume metadata - this
can be view using 'ceph-volume lvm list'.

ceph-volume managed devices are prepared and activated using the
'create' subcommand which differs somewhat from ceph-disk, where
OSD's are activated using udev triggers.

This review also switches to using the charmhelpers zap_disk
function to clean disks prior to use by ceph; this resolves an
outstanding issue with use of Ceph lockbox encryption with
ceph-disk. ceph-volume continues to support the encrypt config
option, applying LUKS based dm-crypt encryption to the LV's
supporting an OSD, with keys stored directly in the MON cluster.

This review also drops support for behaviour in older ceph
releases which are not longer support in Ubuntu (as the author
was not prepared to write new unit test cases for code that
does not ever get run).

Change-Id: I1675b67d364ae6042129a8a717d4bdffff5bde92
"}]
commit_message:
Misc updates for ceph-volume support

Add support for use of the new 'ceph-volume' method for
OSD block device management for Ceph >= 12.2.4 (where the
ceph-volume tool is consistently supported in Ubuntu).

This change requires that block devices be prepared in advance
of calls to ceph-volume (which does not partitioning or setup
of {PV,VG,LV}s).

Block devices are prepare with a single partition of type GPT;
The primary data device for an OSD is prepared with a single
VG and a single LV for bluestore, or two LV's for filestore.

Filestore:

  block /dev/sdb
    pv /dev/sdb1
        vg /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>/osd-data-<OSD-UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>/osd-journal-<OSD-UUID>

Bluestore:

  block /dev/sdb
    pv /dev/sdb1
        vg /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>/osd-block-<OSD-UUID>

If separate Filestore Journal or Bluestore DB and WAL devices
have been configured, appropriate {PV,VG,LV} configuration is
created on the configured block devices.

Filestore with Journal device:

  block /dev/sdb
    pv /dev/sdb1
        vg /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>/osd-data-<OSD-UUID>
  block /dev/sdc
    pv /dev/sdc1
        vg /dev/ceph-journal-<UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-journal-<UUID>/osd-journal-<OSD-UUID>

Bluestore with DB and WAL devices:

  block /dev/sdb
    pv /dev/sdb1
        vg /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-<OSD-UUID>/osd-block-<OSD-UUID>
  block /dev/sdc
    pv /dev/sdc1
        vg /dev/ceph-db-<UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-db-<UUID>/osd-db-<OSD-UUID>
  block /dev/sdd
    pv /dev/sdd1
        vg /dev/ceph-wal-<UUID>
            lv /dev/ceph-wal-<UUID>/osd-wal-<OSD-UUID>

ceph-volume makes extensive use of LVM tags to encode required
Ceph information directly into the LVM volume metadata - this
can be view using 'ceph-volume lvm list'.

ceph-volume managed devices are prepared and activated using the
'create' subcommand which differs somewhat from ceph-disk, where
OSD's are activated using udev triggers.

This review also switches to using the charmhelpers zap_disk
function to clean disks prior to use by ceph; this resolves an
outstanding issue with use of Ceph lockbox encryption with
ceph-disk. ceph-volume continues to support the encrypt config
option, applying LUKS based dm-crypt encryption to the LV's
supporting an OSD, with keys stored directly in the MON cluster.

This review also drops support for behaviour in older ceph
releases which are not longer support in Ubuntu (as the author
was not prepared to write new unit test cases for code that
does not ever get run).

Change-Id: I1675b67d364ae6042129a8a717d4bdffff5bde92

commit_message:
Remove branch heat-tempest-plugin

We need to remove branchs as that will lead to confuse user to
adopt branch and wait for new branch for tests. As we not actually
release anything (the default 0.1.0 was not actually released in
pypi), we should just remove it while we not in some `history`
status.

Change-Id: I14432e8c4c4ee5bf37b67877e8082fe47c4f96cb

Currently the checksum copies to the target as

Change-Id: I99124ac9c602b04db89f875d5c8859faa487cf03
"}]
commit_message:
Copy the checksum to the folder correctly

Currently the checksum copies to the target as
the name 'venv', rather than as the full checksum
file name. This is due to the target not explicitly
being set as a folder, so ansible thinks it's the
file name.

Change-Id: I99124ac9c602b04db89f875d5c8859faa487cf03

commit_message:
nova-status: Migrate to cliff

This is a simple switch over. Updates of the documentation will come
later.

We get to remove some tests since we don't need to duplicate tests from
cliff itself.

Change-Id: I6ed5bdc6d993adb65a8d9ef913707b4663abe518

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: Id15b514bb2b796f928040dc4f767df6627c10e87
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
avoid verbose tracebacks on known errors

- log that no pollsters loaded rather than throwing error
- ipmi are expected to be missing as note says, just debug logs
with details rather than massive traceback.

Closes-Bug: #1747536
Change-Id: Ib592c84dca017e94c66aad0170f0317e514fd747

commit_message:
Fix overcloud node delete after an upgrade

In fbc435ce167eae2c6ac1070be47ad9065561855b, we stopped passing
'parameters' to stack update call. This is backward incompatible
as the 'parameters' set for the stack before an upgrade would take
precedence over the ones set in 'parameter_defaults' of plan env.

Change-Id: Ia1d823386da687154c433136bf22ae6a0291573d
Closes-Bug: #1749636
(cherry picked from commit 7213aa5669492673256db9515933bb1b8ecb4a2b)

commit_message:
Fix overcloud node delete after an upgrade

In fbc435ce167eae2c6ac1070be47ad9065561855b, we stopped passing
'parameters' to stack update call. This is backward incompatible
as the 'parameters' set for the stack before an upgrade would take
precedence over the ones set in 'parameter_defaults' of plan env.

Change-Id: Ia1d823386da687154c433136bf22ae6a0291573d
Closes-Bug: #1749636
(cherry picked from commit 7213aa5669492673256db9515933bb1b8ecb4a2b)

Read bytes for default CA

Cryptography tools (such as the ones in the cryptography library), read
bytes instead of python strings. So lets read the file as such.

Change-Id: I0853f17c8081934e96e01f05df9ec4c6454c1d8a

messages:
[{'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2018-03-26 18:37:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 12924, 'date': '2018-03-26 19:44:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think this might potentially regress on the "no duplicates in the cache" fix. With this change we've now got one spot that is locked for adding entries into the cache and one spot that is not locked that can do it too. If (for whatever reason) the cache entry is evicted after this new locked method returned, but before the call to _create_from_image_cache_or_download() does it's clone then I think we're back to the old behavior where a bunch of parallel requests can create their own cache entries for that image.

I suspect that to keep the requirement of single entries per image and minimize the locking we're going to need refactor _create_from_image_cache_or_download() a little bit so that it can't create entries outside the lock. Simple change for that situation would be to just not let it create new cache entries, it either has to use the cache or download. Trade off being that you are guaranteed a single entry at the price of potentially getting extra cache misses.

I might also be missing something and it works fine.. Been a while since I touched this code. Would be happy to find out I'm wrong :)'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2018-03-26 19:59:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I agree that multiple cache entries can get added, but this only can happens if the entry is evicted between the two calls to _create_from_image_cache_or_download (first one with lock, second with no lock). I don't know how to quantify the likelihood of this happening.

The tradeoff is against the amount of code change. I looked deeper into _create_from_image_cache_or_download and couldn't find an easy way to refactor and still satisfy the use cases and handle the error paths. 

I'm happy to take a second shot at this, but want to be sure I strike the right balance between complexity (of the change) and the value it would add. Plus, I'm mindful of the need to backport this fix quite a ways."}, {'account_id': 21863, 'date': '2018-03-26 20:00:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

Refactor the code that creates a volume from a downloaded glance image
to minimize the scope of the lock that prevents multiple entries in the

Refactor the code that creates a volume from a downloaded glance image
to minimize the scope of the lock that prevents multiple entries in the
volume image cache. Now the lock serializes only the portion of the
code that causes the cache entry to be created. Locking is minimized

commit_message:
Reduce scope of the lock for image volume cache

Refactor the code that creates a volume from a downloaded glance image
to minimize the scope of the lock that prevents multiple entries in the
volume image cache. Now the lock serializes only the portion of the
code that causes the cache entry to be created. Locking is minimized
when the volume is already cached, or when the volume won't be cached.

Closes-Bug: #1758414
Change-Id: I547fb4bcdd4783225b8ca96d157c61ca3bcf4ef4

commit_message:
Test driver-requirements changes on standalone job

This job installs ansible from the driver-requirements.txt file, but we
aren't running the job on changes to this file. Override
irrelevant-files for this job to ensure updates to the ansible
dependency are tested.

Change-Id: I7fca8123ecffe24087db25aff4cd9c41560cf2be

commit_message:
Fix overcloud services connectivity validation

The overcloud services validation uses the Keystone API version 2 to generate a
token. This doesn't work anymore since Queens.

This patch changes the validation to use  API version 3 instead.

Closes-Bug: #1757187

Change-Id: I4e080521a334fca4999b9bc6e3e1bcacd24c476b

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: Ib536056a9b1076895f232e84823e853afd4d77a1
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

I've always worried about the locking here, but the only fix that occurred to me was moving the one call to resource_update be after the pushes to swift etc, but I didn't like how this pushed data out to the secondary stores before the canonical (database) store.

Also I had assumed and hoped that the ordering enforced by the locking around resource_update would avoid races in the swift write. Clearly it does not."}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2017-11-19 20:31:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2017-11-19 21:44:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2017-11-20 00:12:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-17 22:14:48.000000000', 'message': "Resolve race in providing deployment data to Swift

While we are careful to ensure there are no race conditions in updating
the software deployment metadata in the Heat database, there was no such
protection in place for the actual update of the metadata provided to
the server via Swift. In legacy Heat, this race could only occur when
software deployments were created from the REST API or from separate
stacks deploying software to the same server, because resources in the
same stack were handled by a single thread making synchronous calls to
create the software deployments. However, with convergence, resources in
the same stack not only can be processed concurrently but will tend to
be synchronised if they have the same dependencies (since they'll be
triggered by consecutive asynchronous RPC messages).

This handles the race by retrying if a concurrent update is detected by
the time the data has been provided to Swift.

Note that this is only guaranteed to result in the latest data being
available on the assumption that a later write to Swift cannot overwrite
an earlier one that has been accepted. This is probably *not* guaranteed
by Swift in the presence of clock skew. Nonetheless, this should
drastically reduce the failure rate.

Similar caveats would probably apply to Zaqar, although Zaqar nominally
provides FIFO queues (in practice, it likely depends on the backend
used). However, with Zaqar clients receive all updates, not just the
latest one, and os-collect-config stores the deployments contained in
every message. Thus, Zaqar is not affected even assuming out-of-order
arrival.

Change-Id: Ic9a447f27e8c51f91f47f93b0fd1e9710341ec38
Closes-Bug: #1731032
"}, {'created': '2017-11-19 20:23:13.000000000', 'message': "Resolve race in providing deployment data to Swift

commit_message:
Resolve race in providing deployment data to Swift

While we are careful to ensure there are no race conditions in updating
the software deployment metadata in the Heat database, there was no such
protection in place for the actual update of the metadata provided to
the server via Swift. In legacy Heat, this race could only occur when
software deployments were created from the REST API or from separate
stacks deploying software to the same server, because resources in the
same stack were handled by a single thread making synchronous calls to
create the software deployments. However, with convergence, resources in
the same stack not only can be processed concurrently but will tend to
be synchronised if they have the same dependencies (since they'll be
triggered by consecutive asynchronous RPC messages).

This handles the race by retrying if a concurrent update is detected by
the time the data has been provided to Swift.

Note that this is only guaranteed to result in the latest data being
available on the assumption that a later write to Swift cannot overwrite
an earlier one that has been accepted. This is probably *not* guaranteed
by Swift in the presence of clock skew. Nonetheless, this should
drastically reduce the failure rate.

Similar caveats would probably apply to Zaqar, although Zaqar nominally
provides FIFO queues (in practice, it likely depends on the backend
used). However, with Zaqar clients receive all updates, not just the
latest one, and os-collect-config stores the deployments contained in
every message. Thus, Zaqar is not affected even assuming out-of-order
arrival.

Change-Id: Ic9a447f27e8c51f91f47f93b0fd1e9710341ec38
Closes-Bug: #1731032

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-05 17:01:45.000000000', 'message': "Remove incorrect DB retry decorators

The DHCP driver has a retry decorator that expects the function to not
receive a context -yet it does- and that does not create a transaction
or savepoint to be able to retry. These two behaviors are inherently
incorrect.

This patch removes the retry decorator. This is done since it wasn't
doing anything, because of the previously explained reasons. And because
it standarizes to what other drivers are currently doing. The retry can
be added later if we found it's needed.

Change-Id: I8c2f43399913fb6066069dde8017ecffdee7c9f0
"}]
commit_message:
Remove incorrect DB retry decorators

The DHCP driver has a retry decorator that expects the function to not
receive a context -yet it does- and that does not create a transaction
or savepoint to be able to retry. These two behaviors are inherently
incorrect.

This patch removes the retry decorator. This is done since it wasn't
doing anything, because of the previously explained reasons. And because
it standarizes to what other drivers are currently doing. The retry can
be added later if we found it's needed.

Change-Id: I8c2f43399913fb6066069dde8017ecffdee7c9f0

commit_message:
FFU: Fix gnocchi FFU tasks

We need to register facts in order to stop overriding values on
skipping.

Change-Id: I250c8774dd146a99732b5407a52e983b6342bad8

subject: add lower-constraints job
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-25 10:33:48.000000000', 'message': 'add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: Ic9951e7a4ca88dc5138560d44942d4e6d5851480
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: Ic9951e7a4ca88dc5138560d44942d4e6d5851480
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

@Renat: Replying to comments on abandoned patch.

> The change itself looks logical and I believe it fixes the root cause. However, I didn't get the idea of the test. It just calls "test" method that returns a predefined response. Can you explain maybe?
The test is just to ensure that if someone decides to change initializer, test shall remind them to test against empty password setup. It doesn't mean anything logically, I agree.

>Also, did you try it on a real paswordless setup?
I have tested on real setup.

 $ mistral run-action std.ssh '{"cmd":"?", "username":"admin", "host":"10.10.10.10"}'
 {"result": "FortiWeb # FortiWeb # "}

> Soft: we usually use blank lines to split assertions block from data preparations block.
Fixed.'}, {'account_id': 21970, 'date': '2018-03-27 09:27:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Fix std.ssh "password" parameter

Fixes the bug where calling std.ssh action without "password" input was resulting in error.
Closes-bug: #1756272

Change-Id: I5f7af13326933658014a9c42c495d779bec7f14f

subject: Fix user email in federated shadow users
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 5046, 'name': 'Lance Bragstad', 'email': 'lbragstad@redhat.com', 'username': 'ldbragst'}, {'_account_id': 8482, 'name': 'Colleen Murphy', 'email': 'colleen@gazlene.net', 'username': 'krinkle'}, {'_account_id': 15054, 'name': 'wangxiyuan', 'email': 'wangxiyuan1007@gmail.com', 'username': 'wangxiyuan'}, {'_account_id': 17430, 'name': 'yangweiwei', 'email': 'yangweiwei@cmss.chinamobile.com', 'username': 'yangweiwei'}, {'_account_id': 17860, 'name': 'Samuel de Medeiros Queiroz', 'email': 'samueldmq@gmail.com', 'username': 'samueldmq'}, {'_account_id': 21420, 'name': 'Gage Hugo', 'email': 'gagehugo@gmail.com', 'username': 'ghugo'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 17430, 'date': '2018-03-05 10:07:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17430, 'date': '2018-03-05 10:16:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 17430, 'date': '2018-03-05 10:19:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 17430, 'date': '2018-03-06 01:10:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 17430, 'date': '2018-03-06 02:58:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-03-06 08:40:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

LGTM, except a suggestion.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-03-20 20:56:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

Email is not a property of a user. See the sql models[1]. If you see an email property for a user, such as in the example response in the api-ref[2], it's because it was added as an "extra" attribute. If we want to be able to map federated user properties to extra attributes of a shadow user then this needs to be generic enough to do that, not specific to email.

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/keystone/tree/keystone/identity/backends/sql_model.py
[2] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/index.html#create-user'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2018-03-20 21:19:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

> Email is not a property of a user. See the sql models[1]. If you
 > see an email property for a user, such as in the example response
 > in the api-ref[2], it's because it was added as an "extra"
 > attribute. If we want to be able to map federated user properties
 > to extra attributes of a shadow user then this needs to be generic
 > enough to do that, not specific to email.
 > 
 > [1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/keystone/tree/keystone/identity/backends/sql_model.py
 > [2] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/index.html#create-user

Agreed, we should be more generic about what extra properties we are mapping, not just specifically "email".'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-03-21 04:10:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Code-Review

(1 comment)

> Email is not a property of a user. See the sql models[1]. If you
 > see an email property for a user, such as in the example response
 > in the api-ref[2], it's because it was added as an "extra"
 > attribute. If we want to be able to map federated user properties
 > to extra attributes of a shadow user then this needs to be generic
 > enough to do that, not specific to email.
 > 
 > [1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/keystone/tree/keystone/identity/backends/sql_model.py
 > [2] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/index.html#create-user

Agree. generic way is better.'}, {'account_id': 17430, 'date': '2018-03-21 08:14:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > > Email is not a property of a user. See the sql models[1]. If you
 > > see an email property for a user, such as in the example response
 > > in the api-ref[2], it's because it was added as an "extra"
 > > attribute. If we want to be able to map federated user properties
 > > to extra attributes of a shadow user then this needs to be
 > generic
 > > enough to do that, not specific to email.
 > >
 > > [1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/keystone/tree/keystone/identity/backends/sql_model.py
 > > [2] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/index.html#create-user
 > 
 > Agree. generic way is better.

Ok, thanks. I will recheck it.'}, {'account_id': 17430, 'date': '2018-03-21 08:41:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > > Email is not a property of a user. See the sql models[1]. If you
 > > see an email property for a user, such as in the example response
 > > in the api-ref[2], it's because it was added as an "extra"
 > > attribute. If we want to be able to map federated user properties
 > > to extra attributes of a shadow user then this needs to be
 > generic
 > > enough to do that, not specific to email.
 > >
 > > [1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/keystone/tree/keystone/identity/backends/sql_model.py
 > > [2] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/index.html#create-user
 > 
 > Agreed, we should be more generic about what extra properties we
 > are mapping, not just specifically "email".

I have found this, please look at:http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/keystone/tree/keystone/federation/utils.py#MAPPING_SCHEMA . Here, we can see the fedetated user who can have 4 properties：'id', 'name', 'email' and 'domain'. So, I think this patch just highlights 'email'. If we set this for general, and the rule can not contain. It is also rewardless.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-03-21 09:17:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

> 
 > I have found this, please look at:http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/keystone/tree/keystone/federation/utils.py#MAPPING_SCHEMA
 > . Here, we can see the fedetated user who can have 4
 > properties：'id', 'name', 'email' and 'domain'. So, I think this
 > patch just highlights 'email'. If we set this for general, and the
 > rule can not contain. It is also rewardless.

Oh, good find. I guess it's fine to treat email as a special property.

I agree with XiYuan's comment about not needing a new method in mapped.py and made a minor comment on the tests, will have a closer look later."}, {'account_id': 17430, 'date': '2018-03-21 09:22:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > >
 > > I have found this, please look at:http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/keystone/tree/keystone/federation/utils.py#MAPPING_SCHEMA
 > > . Here, we can see the fedetated user who can have 4
 > > properties：'id', 'name', 'email' and 'domain'. So, I think this
 > > patch just highlights 'email'. If we set this for general, and
 > the
 > > rule can not contain. It is also rewardless.
 > 
 > Oh, good find. I guess it's fine to treat email as a special
 > property.
 > 
 > I agree with XiYuan's comment about not needing a new method in
 > mapped.py and made a minor comment on the tests, will have a closer
 > look later.

Good, I will update later."}, {'account_id': 17430, 'date': '2018-03-21 10:05:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 17430, 'date': '2018-03-22 01:31:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > >
 > > I have found this, please look at:http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/keystone/tree/keystone/federation/utils.py#MAPPING_SCHEMA
 > > . Here, we can see the fedetated user who can have 4
 > > properties：'id', 'name', 'email' and 'domain'. So, I think this
 > > patch just highlights 'email'. If we set this for general, and
 > the
 > > rule can not contain. It is also rewardless.
 > 
 > Oh, good find. I guess it's fine to treat email as a special
 > property.
 > 
 > I agree with XiYuan's comment about not needing a new method in
 > mapped.py and made a minor comment on the tests, will have a closer
 > look later.

Hello, Colleen Murphy, I have seen /keystone / keystone/tests/unit/test_shadow_users.py carefully again. 'Email' can not be a attribute of Federated_user, and it is in 'extra' attributes of 'User'. 
And in this patch, we just map the 'faderated user' to user. So I think  a variable may be better."}, {'account_id': 17430, 'date': '2018-03-22 01:37:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-03-22 22:26:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

> 
 > Hello, Colleen Murphy, I have seen /keystone / keystone/tests/unit/test_shadow_users.py
 > carefully again. 'Email' can not be a attribute of Federated_user,
 > and it is in 'extra' attributes of 'User'.
 > And in this patch, we just map the 'faderated user' to user. So I
 > think  a variable may be better.

FederatedUser and User are joined together so in this test case email is essentially a property of the federated_user object. But it's a minor detail, I'm not that concerned about it."}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-03-23 03:35:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

> > (1 comment)
 > >
 > > > Email is not a property of a user. See the sql models[1]. If
 > you
 > > > see an email property for a user, such as in the example
 > response
 > > > in the api-ref[2], it's because it was added as an "extra"
 > > > attribute. If we want to be able to map federated user
 > properties
 > > > to extra attributes of a shadow user then this needs to be
 > > generic
 > > > enough to do that, not specific to email.
 > > >
 > > > [1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/keystone/tree/keystone/identity/backends/sql_model.py
 > > > [2] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/index.html#create-user
 > >
 > > Agreed, we should be more generic about what extra properties we
 > > are mapping, not just specifically "email".
 > 
 > I have found this, please look at:http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/keystone/tree/keystone/federation/utils.py#MAPPING_SCHEMA
 > . Here, we can see the fedetated user who can have 4
 > properties：'id', 'name', 'email' and 'domain'. So, I think this
 > patch just highlights 'email'. If we set this for general, and the
 > rule can not contain. It is also rewardless.

nice find.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-03-26 18:16:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 17430, 'date': '2018-03-27 01:38:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> (2 comments)

Lance Bragstad, if 'email' is set in federated_dict, we should change the 'Federated_user' model. And then if we would change the email for the user, or we show the user, 'email' has already been as 'extra' attributes in user model. We should consider local user or federated user as equal."}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-03-27 21:25:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-03-28 01:58:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-03-28 07:21:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

recheck'}]

commit_message:
Fix user email in federated shadow users

When the federated rule contains 'email' in user and we should set
email for the federated user. Also, if the federated user changes the
email info, it should be chenged too.

Change-Id: Ib17172c34bd65d5236cbfc192b3a3f2b221411ef
Closes-Bug: #1746599

LGTM.
Should we consider adding an API path for health report queries?
I know some folks query neutron-server for the API version[1] in order to monitor its health (also, would be nice to have such API call in Octavia for that purpose only). 

In any case, this is just a thought and should not be in the scope of this patch.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-27 16:36:28.000000000', 'message': "Fix logging level for keystone auth bypass

For some paths (version discovery) we don't require keystone authentication.
Previously each hit to these paths logged an INFO level message for the access.
However, some users were using / for their API health monitoring which led
to excessive log entries.
This patch changes this logging level down to DEBUG.

Change-Id: I68a6b66ddb2bf184528f11e73f411e0301f162e7
Story: 2001743
Task: 12101
"}]
commit_message:
Fix logging level for keystone auth bypass

For some paths (version discovery) we don't require keystone authentication.
Previously each hit to these paths logged an INFO level message for the access.
However, some users were using / for their API health monitoring which led
to excessive log entries.
This patch changes this logging level down to DEBUG.

Change-Id: I68a6b66ddb2bf184528f11e73f411e0301f162e7
Story: 2001743
Task: 12101

commit_message:
Add no_log to prevent leaking

Current galera install leaks sql passwords in standard output, patching
it with no_log.

Change-Id: Ia170e4f25e35984e68b4cd47c3d964a034236d11
(cherry picked from commit 3665575c52e54453cab3a938aa8c9628152a7c88)
